cheatsheets.name: File Transfer Methods for security work
cheatsheets.description: Comprehensive guide to file transfer techniques for uploading tools to targets and exfiltrating data back to attack machine

how_to_recognize: You have initial access (shell/RDP) and need to upload enumeration tools
Need to transfer exploit payloads to target system
Must exfiltrate proof.txt, database dumps, or sensitive files
HTTP downloads are blocked by firewall/proxy
when_to_look_for: Immediately after gaining initial foothold (upload linpeas/winPEAS)
In restricted environments (alternative transfer methods needed)

scenarios.title: Scenario 1: Initial Windows Shell - Upload Enumeration Tools
scenarios.context: You have cmd.exe shell on Windows target via web shell or RCE. Need to upload winPEAS.exe for privilege escalation enumeration.
scenarios.approach: Setup HTTP server on Kali, use certutil as first choice (Windows built-in LOLBin), fallback to PowerShell if certutil blocked
scenarios.expected_outcome: winPEAS.exe successfully downloaded to C:\Windows\Temp\ within 30 seconds. Verify with 'dir' command showing correct file size.
scenarios.why_this_works: Certutil bypasses most AppLocker policies because it's a legitimate Windows certificate tool. PowerShell WebClient is fastest for large files. HTTP port 80/8000 usually allowed for outbound connections.

scenarios.title: Scenario 2: Linux SSH Access - Transfer Exploit Binary
scenarios.context: You have SSH credentials for low-privileged user on Linux target. Found kernel vulnerability (CVE-2021-4034 PwnKit), need to transfer compiled exploit.
scenarios.approach: Use SCP if SSH access available (fastest/cleanest), otherwise setup HTTP server and wget/curl download
scenarios.expected_outcome: Exploit binary transferred with execute permissions to /tmp/exploit. File hash matches source to ensure integrity.
scenarios.why_this_works: SCP is bidirectional and encrypted, cleanest method with SSH access. Wget/curl are ubiquitous on Linux. /tmp/ is world-writable fallback if home directory has restrictions.

scenarios.title: Scenario 3: Windows Target - HTTP Blocked, Use SMB
scenarios.context: Windows Server 2016 target with strict egress filtering - HTTP/HTTPS outbound blocked by firewall. Port 445 (SMB) allowed for internal network traffic.
scenarios.approach: Setup Impacket SMB server on Kali, access files directly from UNC path or copy to local disk
scenarios.expected_outcome: Files accessible via \\<KALI_IP>\share\. Can execute tools directly from share or copy locally. 10-50x faster than HTTP for large files.
scenarios.why_this_works: Port 445 often allowed on internal networks for legitimate file sharing. SMB blends with normal traffic. Can execute directly from share without writing to disk (stealthier).

scenarios.title: Scenario 4: Exfiltrate Proof.txt from Windows
scenarios.context: Gained SYSTEM privileges on Windows target. Need to exfiltrate C:\Users\Administrator\Desktop\proof.txt to Kali for flag submission.
scenarios.approach: Setup uploadserver on Kali, use PowerShell Invoke-RestMethod to POST file, fallback to SMB if HTTP blocked, use pure PowerShell TCP if nc.exe unavailable
scenarios.expected_outcome: proof.txt appears on Kali within 5 seconds. MD5 hash matches to verify integrity. File contains 32-character flag.
scenarios.why_this_works: Uploadserver accepts POST uploads at /upload endpoint. PowerShell Invoke-RestMethod is clean HTTP upload. SMB copy is fastest for any file size. Pure PowerShell TCP works when nc.exe not available. All methods preserve exact file contents.

scenarios.title: Scenario 5: Exfiltrate Database from Linux
scenarios.context: Compromised web application, dumped MySQL database to /tmp/dump.sql (150MB). Need to exfiltrate to Kali for credential analysis.
scenarios.approach: For large files, use netcat or curl upload to avoid memory issues. Compress first if slow network.
scenarios.expected_outcome: 150MB database transferred within 2-5 minutes on local network. Verify file size matches source. Extract credentials for lateral movement.
scenarios.why_this_works: Curl handles large files efficiently with streaming. Netcat is simplest (no dependencies) and works when HTTP blocked. Compression reduces transfer time but requires additional step.

scenarios.title: Scenario 6: Restricted Shell - No wget/curl Available
scenarios.context: Linux target with minimal installed tools. No wget, curl, nc, scp available. Only bash and basic utilities.
scenarios.approach: Use bash /dev/tcp pseudo-device for raw TCP connection to download files
scenarios.expected_outcome: File downloaded using only bash built-in features. No external commands executed (stealthier in logs).
scenarios.why_this_works: Bash /dev/tcp creates TCP connections without external tools. Works when all download utilities removed. Requires bash (not sh/dash). Some systems compile bash without /dev/tcp support.

scenarios.title: Scenario 7: Copy/Paste Exfiltration - No Network Transfer
scenarios.context: Windows target via RDP with clipboard access. Network file transfers monitored/blocked by DLP. Need to exfiltrate small config file (5KB).
scenarios.approach: Encode file as base64, copy output, paste to Kali, decode
scenarios.expected_outcome: File encoded as text, copied via clipboard, decoded on Kali matching original. Bypasses network monitoring.
scenarios.why_this_works: Base64 converts binary to printable text safe for clipboard. ~33% size increase. Only practical for files <1MB due to manual copy/paste. Works when all network transfers blocked.

sections.title: Phase 1: Setup Attack Machine Servers
sections.notes: Start these servers on Kali BEFORE attempting file transfers. Run in separate terminal windows to monitor connections.

sections.title: Phase 2: Windows Target Downloads (Tools IN)
sections.notes: Transfer enumeration tools, exploits, or utilities TO Windows target. Try methods in order: certutil (fastest/stealthiest) → PowerShell → SMB (if HTTP blocked) → bitsadmin (background).

commands.shows: Command completes without output (silence means success)

sections.title: Phase 3: Linux Target Downloads (Tools IN)
sections.notes: Transfer tools TO Linux target. wget is most common → curl if wget unavailable → /dev/tcp if no tools available.

commands.shows: HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 200 OK

sections.title: Phase 4: Windows Exfiltration (Data OUT)
sections.notes: Transfer proof.txt, hashes, databases FROM Windows target to Kali. PowerShell upload is cleanest → SMB for large files → netcat if HTTP blocked → pure PowerShell TCP if nc.exe unavailable.

sections.title: Phase 5: Linux Exfiltration (Data OUT)
sections.notes: Transfer data FROM Linux target to Kali. Curl upload for HTTP → netcat for raw TCP → SCP if SSH credentials available.

sections.title: Phase 6: Netcat & Raw TCP Transfers
sections.notes: Universal transfer method when HTTP/SMB unavailable. Works on both Linux and Windows. Receiver starts first with -l flag, sender connects. Use pure PowerShell TCP if nc.exe not available on Windows.

sections.title: Phase 7: Alternative Methods (Restricted Environments)
sections.notes: Use when standard methods fail due to firewalls, missing tools, or security controls.

commands.shows: Password prompt appears (if using password auth)
